results.title: ‘Party Down’ Gets It: Food Service Is No Party
results.abstract: The Starz sitcom about the mundane lives of L.A. cater waiters is a smart, funny antidote to the shows and films that focus on chefs and glamorize the business.

multimedia.caption: “Party Down” returns after 13 years to celebrate the in-between moments of food service and life.
multimedia.copyright: Leroy and Rose Agency, via Starz

results.title: Spring Comes Early With This Bright, Cozy Dinner
results.abstract: A mustardy beet salad, a creamy chicken main and a warm lemon pudding: This menu from David Tanis looks ahead in all the right ways.

multimedia.caption: This creamy chicken, which celebrates fresh spring vegetables and herbs, takes its cues from the French preparation known as blanquette.

results.title: He Taught Americans to Cook Indian Food. Now He’s on His Final Chapter.
results.abstract: Raghavan Iyer, whose books and spirited teaching spread the cuisine, is using his last days to get familiar comfort foods to patients like himself.

multimedia.caption: As the end of his life nears, Raghavan Iyer is publishing a new book and promoting the importance of feeding patients foods that speak to their origins and conditions.
multimedia.copyright: Nate Ryan for The New York Times

results.title: For Perfectly Cooked Rice Every Time, Try Your Microwave
results.abstract: It may seem sacrilegious to stovetop loyalists, but when it comes to consistency, this household appliance is a weeknight meal’s best friend.

results.title: A Vegetable Soup That Delicately Balances Sweet and Sour
results.abstract: Full of lemongrass, tamarind and tofu, this light winter dish is a little different each time you make it — and that’s part of the allure, Yewande Komolafe writes.

multimedia.caption: In this light soup, tofu (soft or silken) absorbs the essence of the fragrant broth and melts in your mouth with every spoonful.
multimedia.copyright: Kelly Marshall for The New York Times. Food Stylist: Roscoe Betsill.

results.title: In Majority-Black New Orleans, Chefs Are Rewriting ‘Whitewashed’ History
results.abstract: A new generation is exploring how the city’s celebrated food owes as much to West African and Caribbean cuisines as to French cooking.
results.byline: By Brett Anderson and Rita Harper

multimedia.caption: New Orleans chefs, restaurateurs and scholars have been rethinking the city’s culinary history. Front row, from left: Serigne Mbaye, Afua Richardson, Nina Compton, Lisa Nelson, Zella Palmer, Martha Wiggins, Edgar Chase IV. Back row, from left: Prince Lobo, Dr. Howard Conyers, Robert Manos, Charly Pierre.

New Orleans chefs, restaurateurs and scholars have been rethinking the city’s culinary history. results.title: Raymond Trollat, Who Took a Hilly Wine Region to New Heights, Dies at 91
results.abstract: Few knew the Northern Rhône Valley when he began growing grapes and making wine in the 1940s. By the time he retired, the region, and his wines, were world famous.

multimedia.caption: Raymond Trollat, left, in 1983 with Kermit Lynch, Gérard Chave and Ernest Trollat, Raymond’s father, in Mr. Trollat’s cellar. “What stood out about Raymond was his totally funky approach to winemaking,” Mr. Lynch said.
multimedia.copyright: Gail Skoff

multimedia.caption: Raymond Trollat, left, in 1983 with Kermit Lynch, Gérard Chave and Ernest Trollat, Raymond’s father, in Mr. Trollat’s cellar. “What stood out about Raymond was his totally funky approach to winemaking,” Mr. Lynch said.
multimedia.copyright: Gail Skoff

multimedia.caption: Raymond Trollat, left, in 1983 with Kermit Lynch, Gérard Chave and Ernest Trollat, Raymond’s father, in Mr. Trollat’s cellar. “What stood out about Raymond was his totally funky approach to winemaking,” Mr. Lynch said.
multimedia.copyright: Gail Skoff

results.title: William Greenberg Jr., Baker Who Sweetened Manhattan, Dies at 97
results.abstract: He used poker winnings to open a modest bakery in 1946 that grew into an artisanal dessert empire, tempting New Yorkers of all ages.

multimedia.caption: William Greenberg Jr. wielding his pastry gun to embellish a colossus of a cake created for President Bill Clinton’s 50th birthday in 1996. Mr. Greenberg was a maestro of frosting and cake decoration.
